1.text:
Good afternoon.
I’m sorry I’m not the most interesting

14.text:
Jeremy in British politics right now - 
but I do have the most interesting job, and

29.text:
there is no greater privilege in government
than being responsible for our NHS.

35.text:
To do that I’m supported by a fantastic
ministerial team.

40.text:
So let me start by thanking Alistair Burt
for his avuncular kindness, Ben Gummer for

47.text:
his youthful energy, Jane Ellison for her
good-natured calmness, George Freeman for

55.text:
his great passion, and David Prior for his
worldly wisdom - what a team and I am lucky

66.text:
to have them.
My day as Health Secretary usually starts

76.text:
the same way.
When I arrive in the office there’s a pink

80.text:
folder waiting for me on my desk.
It contains a letter from a member of the

87.text:
public about something that’s gone wrong
in the NHS.

91.text:
Of course these letters are not typical of
much brilliant care that happens every day

98.text:
in our hospitals and surgeries.
But I know that if I ignore the things that

102.text:
go wrong, others will too.
I’ll never forget one letter.

108.text:
A lady wrote to me about her brother who worked
as a call centre manager.

114.text:
He went to hospital for an operation because
his back was in agony from a pinched nerve.

119.text:
Things didn’t go well, including a feeding
tube inserted incorrectly, a catheter left

125.text:
blocked for 2 days and cries for help left
unanswered in what ended up being a horrible

134.text:
last two weeks of his life.
As Health Secretary you have a very simple

141.text:
choice.
Do you ignore these problems and try to sweep

146.text:
them under the carpet or do we confront them
head on and sort them out?

151.text:
It’s a political choice, too.
Because it’s never comfortable for any government

157.text:
to admit when things go wrong.
But if you care for something - as David Cameron

164.text:
always has for our NHS - you want it to be
the best.

174.text:
I’ll tell you someone else who wanted it
to be the best. Nye Bevan, the Labour Welsh

188.text:
firebrand who set up the NHS in 1948 - four
years after a Conservative Health Minister

194.text:
suggested it.
Now Bevan would probably turn in his grave

200.text:
if he knew he was being quoted at a Conservative
Conference.

205.text:
But he used a good phrase to explain what
he was trying to do.

210.text:
He said he wanted to ‘universalise the best.’
If the NHS is about equity, it has to be about

220.text:
excellence.
If someone wealthy lives near a hospital with

226.text:
problems, they have alternatives.
But everyone else depends on that hospital.

232.text:
And if we don’t do everything in our power
to improve the quality of that hospital we

237.text:
betray them - and we betray the founding vision
of the NHS which says that however fraught

244.text:
your life, however frail your voice our society
has not forgotten you because we have an NHS.

258.text:
The vision of Nye Bevan before.
The vision of a one-nation Conservative Party

263.text:
today.
But a vision that, in office, the modern Labour

268.text:
party forgot.
Their pride in having set up the NHS blinded

273.text:
them to the dangers of ignoring poor care.
Targets mattered more than people.

280.text:
Good news mattered more than good care.
So when we faced up to the problems of Mid

286.text:
Staffs - which happened on Labour’s watch
- they said we were 'running down the NHS.’

291.text:
They even tried to vote down the law that
set up an independent Chief Inspector of Hospitals.

300.text:
The true party of the NHS insists on high
standards for patients in every corner of

308.text:
the NHS, however tough and challenging that
might be.

318.text:
And although there is much still to do, the
results so far speak for themselves.

323.text:
24 major hospitals have been put into special
measures in the two years since the Francis

330.text:
Report into Mid Staffs.
People said no one would want to work at those

335.text:
hospitals.
That they would sink in a spiral of decline.

339.text:
That things would go from bad to worse.
Instead those Trusts changed their boards,

346.text:
recruited hundreds of doctors and nurses,
and transformed the care they give. 9 have

353.text:
already come out of special measures and according
to one study up to 450 lives are being saved

359.text:
every year as a result.
So let’s recognise the brilliant work of

365.text:
the doctors and nurses at Basildon, Tameside,
King’s Lynn, East Lancashire, George Eliott,

374.text:
Bucks, Goole, Lincoln and Heatherwood and
Wexham Park who have worked so hard to turn

380.text:
their Trusts round.
Across the NHS the effort to learn those lessons

396.text:
and improve care has never been higher. And
I want to pay tribute to some of the achievements

404.text:
in the last 5 years.
Record numbers of doctors and nurses.

410.text:
MRSA and CDiff rates halved.
Mixed sex wards eliminated.

418.text:
Cancer survival rates at a record high.
Maximum waiting times introduced for mental

424.text:
health.
A million more operations every year.

432.text:
And public satisfaction going up, now at near
record levels.

439.text:
Last year the independent Commonwealth Fund
said that under the Coalition our NHS had

446.text:
become the best healthcare system in the world
- better than France, better than Germany,

453.text:
better than the US - and here’s something
for rugby fans - better than Australia! - so

459.text:
let’s hear it for all 1.3 million NHS staff
working so hard in such challenging circumstances

467.text:
- the nurses, cooks, surgeons, cleaners, clinicians,
physiotherapists, mental health professionals,

476.text:
porters and volunteers.
We are proud of every single one of you.

482.text:
And not just the NHS - let’s recognise those
working for local authorities to support our

489.text:
vital social care sector and public health
programmes.

494.text:
As you struggle with the pressures of a rapidly
ageing population, you too have had many successes.

502.text:
Integrated care finally becoming a reality
thanks to the Better Care Fund.

507.text:
Smoking rates at an all-time low.
Teenage drinking down and drug use halved

515.text:
in decade.
Teenage pregnancies at a 40 year low.

520.text:
Yes the gaps between richer and poorer areas
are still too high but we are making progress

528.text:
- and Conservative governments and Conservative
Councils will never allow young people to

535.text:
have their future taken away by accidents
of birth, or debt, or dependency, or addictions

542.text:
which destroy their dreams and take years
off their lives.

555.text:
I have a simple plan.
I want our party, the Conservative Party,

562.text:
to be the party of the NHS.
Some people listen to our opponents and think

569.text:
differently.
So we have to prove it.

574.text:
And we are.
For two elections in a row, David Cameron

579.text:
and George Osborne promised more money for
the NHS than any other party.

586.text:
The extra £10 billion we have committed to
the NHS this parliament is a massive commitment

592.text:
in the face of the worst deficit in our peacetime
history.

596.text:
But what Conservatives know is that a strong
NHS needs a strong economy.

604.text:
We also know high quality public services
are not just about what taxpayers put in - they

609.text:
are about what the public gets out.
That whether it’s schools, or police, or

614.text:
hospitals the truly progressive party is the
one that fights for higher standards and tackles

619.text:
problems head on.
Like the issue of people who die when they

628.text:
shouldn’t because they are admitted to hospital
over a weekend.

635.text:
When we said in our manifesto, we were committed
to 7 day services, it wasn’t just about

642.text:
the convenience of evening and weekend GP
appointments, important though that is.

648.text:
It was to end the scandal of 11,000 excess
deaths each year because of what is known

657.text:
as the ‘weekend effect’ in hospitals.
We are not asking junior doctors to work longer

665.text:
hours - that wouldn’t be safe.
Nor is it our intention to cut doctors’

670.text:
pay - and it is utterly irresponsible to try
and scare people into believing we are.

679.text:
But we do want to support the many doctors
who do work weekends with properly staffed

690.text:
shifts, safe working hours and 7 day diagnostic
services so that patients are not put at risk.

697.text:
So I say to those people working very hard
right now on the frontline, stand beside us

704.text:
as we address this.
What’s good for patients is good for doctors,

709.text:
so be our partners in building the safest,
highest quality healthcare system in the world.

724.text:
Now safe care is not just about weekend services.
How many of you know that there are around

741.text:
200 deaths in our hospitals that could have
been avoided every week?

745.text:
We’re no better or worse than other countries
- but that’s like a plane crash a week because

757.text:
of mistakes we shouldn’t be making.
Part of the reason is that across the world,

765.text:
often the culture in hospitals is wrong.
Put simply we make it too difficult for doctors

773.text:
and nurses to speak out about poor care.
Too many worry that if they own up to making

779.text:
a mistake or blow the whistle on poor care
they will be fired - as they sometimes are.

788.text:
As a result not only do we cause patients
and families untold anguish as they search

794.text:
for the truth, we lose the chance to learn
from those mistakes.

800.text:
In our hospitals we need an honesty culture
not a blame culture - which is why I asked

807.text:
Sir Robert Francis to do the first ever independent
review into whistleblowing.

814.text:
Some people say we don’t have enough money
in the NHS to deliver the high standards of

819.text:
care we all want.
But it isn’t a choice between standards

824.text:
or money.
If someone catches MRSA in hospital, they

828.text:
stay in hospital for longer costing the NHS
more money.

833.text:
Safer care costs less, not more.
So let’s eliminate the waste from unsafe

839.text:
care and like the rest of the public sector
make efficiencies and raise standards at the

845.text:
same time.
Our best hospitals like the Salford Royal

849.text:
down the road, Frimley in Surrey and Northumbria
show us it can be done, so let’s learn from

855.text:
them and never waver in our commitment to
high quality care in every corner of the NHS.

868.text:
Now I want to talk about GPs.
Let me tell you about a wonderful GP in Essex.

877.text:
Every week he asks his practice nurses to
write the names of any patients they are worried

884.text:
about on post-it notes.
He then personally calls them to check up

889.text:
how they are.
We have many GPs like him.

896.text:
But many more who want to be like him, but
find they simply can’t deliver that kind

902.text:
of personal care because of targets and tick-boxes
and rising appointment lists.

908.text:
That kind of personal, proactive care should
not be a relic of a bygone age.

916.text:
It’s how we’ll make the NHS sustainable
by keeping people healthy and happy at home

921.text:
without needing expensive hospital treatment.
So on Sunday we set out plans for a new contract

930.text:
that will support GPs to deliver evening and
weekend care by working with other local surgeries

936.text:
and clinical staff.
We also announced a £750m scheme to improve

941.text:
primary care premises and technology to allow
surgeries to expand and modernise their services.

948.text:
And it’s why we are backing the NHS England
Five Year Forward View which will connect

953.text:
the services offered by GPs, local hospitals
and social care system to offer integrated

961.text:
care closer to home.
Right for GPs, right for the NHS and the social

966.text:
care system - and most importantly right for
the patients.

972.text:
Let me finish with a point about the culture
in the NHS, perhaps the most important point

978.text:
of all.
If we’re going to change the culture to

983.text:
make it more focused on patients, governments
too are going to have to change the way they

993.text:
run it.
The NHS is the fifth largest organisation

999.text:
in the world - only beaten in size by McDonalds
(now you weren’t expecting the Health Secretary

1013.text:
to mention McDonalds were you?), and also
Walmart, the Red Army and the US Department

1023.text:
of Defense.
Faced with such a large bureaucracy, health

1029.text:
secretaries of all parties - quite understandably
- have tried to make changes by introducing

1035.text:
targets.
Individually those targets have worked - bringing

1041.text:
down waiting times, speeding up A & Es, improving
cancer care and so on - but collectively they

1049.text:
have undermined the professionalism and sense
of vocation that should be at the heart of

1054.text:
medicine.
Now I’m not going to scrap every target

1058.text:
because patients should never have to wait
too long for treatment.

1062.text:
But we do believe peer-review, transparency
and openness about performance is a better

1070.text:
way to drive up standards than endless new
targets.

1075.text:
So last year I launched a new website, MyNHS,
where we publish more information about NHS

1089.text:
performance than any other healthcare system
in the world.

1095.text:
You can see how safe your local hospital is;
how good the food is;

1101.text:
how good your local GP surgery or care home
is;

1105.text:
the mortality rate for your surgeon
and over 693,000 other pieces of data.

1111.text:
From next May we will go further with assessments
on MyNHS about the overall quality of mental

1119.text:
health and cancer care, area by area,
and because we still have too many avoidable

1127.text:
deaths we’ll also publish avoidable death
rates hospital by hospital.

1134.text:
Some people have criticised this as 'naming
and shaming’ - but there are no sanctions

1138.text:
or punishments for those with low scores,
just the opportunity to improve.

1145.text:
Transparency for patients, not targets for
politicians.

1149.text:
A new culture where patients always come first.
Conference, our healthcare system has always

1159.text:
faced challenges.
And our strongest weapon in the face of those

1164.text:
challenges has always been our willingness
to innovate.

1168.text:
We discovered penicillin, we pioneered anaesthetics,
we made the first hip replacements possible

1175.text:
and we unravelled DNA.
We gave Britain the NHS - and the world its

1181.text:
first universal healthcare system.
And we’re not stopping.

1186.text:
We will soon be a world leader in curing rare
diseases with our genomics programme;

1194.text:
a world leader in using transparency to drive
up clinical standards;

1198.text:
a world leader in improving hospital safety.
All backed with the resources of a strong

1204.text:
economy only a Conservative government can
deliver.

1208.text:
Some say with pressures mounting and money
so tight, we need to rein back our ambitions.

1216.text:
But I say the only way to meet the challenges
we face is to raise our ambitions, face the

1222.text:
storms and draw strength from the wonderful
commitment of NHS staff and the British people

1228.text:
who stand foursquare behind them.
Because with a one nation Conservative government,

1234.text:
for our NHS the best is yet to come.
Thank you.
